description: Hungary announced a two week curfew starting on March 28 where citizens could not leave their house except to go to work or run essential errands. Those above 65 could only visit groceries stores, markets and pharmacies from 9-12 am, citizens below that age are only allowed in these establishments outside of these hours.

Hungary announced a two week curfew starting on March 28 where citizens could not leave their house except to go to work or run essential errands. On April 9 Hungary extended the curfew indefinitely. UPDATE: Hungary originally announced a two week curfew but has extended the curfew indefinitely

Hungary announced a two week curfew starting on March 28 where citizens could not leave their house except to go to work or run essential errands. Those above 65 could only visit groceries stores, markets and pharmacies from 9-12 am, citizens below that age are only allowed in these establishments outside of these hours. UPDATE: The curfew measured are lifted everywhere in the country except for in Budapest from 4 May 2020.

description: Hungary introduces new restrictions on cross-border travel from July 15, 2020. Countries will be divided into "green", "yellow" or "red" categories. Foreign nationals arriving from a "yellow" country will be required to go into quarantine for 14 days on their arrival in Hungary, whilst those arriving from a "red" country will be denied entry. Hungarian nationals are permitted entry if arriving from a "red" country; however, two negative tests will be required before they may leave quarantine.

description: Hungary announced a partial lockdown from November 11, 2020. A nationwide general curfew will be imposed between 8 p.m. and 5 a.m. with an exception for those commuting to work. Businesses will be required to close by 7 p.m., restaurants will be limited to home delivery, sporting events will be held in empty stadiums, and family gatherings will be limited to 10 people. Universities and high schools will make the transition to digital education, while preschools, kindergartens and classes for children 14 and under will remain open. The restrictions will remain in place for 30 days, after which they may be extended.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Hungary announced a partial lockdown from November 11, 2020. A nationwide general curfew will be imposed between 8 p.m. and 5 a.m. with an exception for those commuting to work. Businesses will be required to close by 7 p.m., restaurants will be limited to home delivery, sporting events will be held in empty stadiums, and family gatherings will be limited to 10 people. Universities and high schools will make the transition to digital education, while preschools, kindergartens and classes for children 14 and under will remain open. The restrictions will remain in place for 30 days, after which they may be extended. UPDATE: The Hungarian government extended the lockdown including the 8 pm curfew at least until January 11, 2021, as of December 7, 2020.

description: Hungary announced a partial lockdown from November 11, 2020. A nationwide general curfew will be imposed between 8 p.m. and 5 a.m. with an exception for those commuting to work. Businesses will be required to close by 7 p.m., restaurants will be limited to home delivery, sporting events will be held in empty stadiums, and family gatherings will be limited to 10 people. Universities and high schools will make the transition to digital education, while preschools, kindergartens and classes for children 14 and under will remain open. The restrictions will remain in place for 30 days, after which they may be extended. UPDATE: Hungary introduces stricter lockdown measures as of March 8, 2021. Shops, with the exception of food stores, pharmacies and petrol stations, will have to be closed and services, with the exception of private health care, suspended between March 8 and 22. Kindergartens and primary schools will be closed from March 8 until April 7.
